#HealthShareReform is out weekly dive into the top trends, articles, and opinion on health care throughout social media:

1. AK: Ketchikan nurses write open letter of grievances in PeaceHealth negotiations Barbara Lander, RN at PeaceHealth Ketchikan Medical Center, wrote a letter to the editor detailing grievances between nurses and PeaceHealth: Post by State of Reform

2. WA: “Not a tax” Wellness Trust obligates hospitals to give six percent New legislation proposes the establishment of the Washington Wellness Trust account, a new obligation (not a tax). The Department of Health (DOH) would calculate six percent of annual patient revenue for the State Treasury to support state behavioral and population health activities: Not a tax–Wellness Trust obligates hospitals to give six percent http://t.co/4xmStctJGd via @stateofreform — State of Reform (@StateofReform) February 16, 2015

3. WA: Telemedicine reaches Senate milestone New bill, SB 5175, earned unanimous approval from the State Senate on Wednesday, marking a huge step forward for telemedicine in an effort that began in 2013, and which failed on two previous occasions to make it out of the legislature. WA: Telemedicine reaches Senate milestone http://t.co/UuWDZcndIM via @stateofreform #mhealth #telemedicine — Manu Bains (@MissManuBains) February 16, 2015

4. CMS announces New Affordable Care Act initiative to encourage better oncology care The U.S. Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) today announced a new multi-payer payment and care delivery model to support better care coordination for cancer care as part of the Department’s ongoing efforts to improve the quality of care patients receive and spend health care dollars more wisely, contributing to healthier communities: CMS announces New Affordable Care Act initiative to encourage better oncology care http://t.co/QakTpXkx64 via @stateofreform — Kameron Gifford (@KameronGifford) February 13, 2015

5. OR: Senate Bill seeks to curb senior executive salaries at non-profit hospitals An older story is finding new traction. Looks like we got an early scoop. Oregon State Senator Chip Shields (D-22) and Representative Mitch Greenlick (D-33) introduced a bill that puts stricter regulations on the salary of executives at nonprofit hospitals in state. The bill follows ongoing media coverage of Oregon hospital executives exhibiting salary increases that are double those of the nation. Read more below: #Oregon Senate Bill seeks to curb senior executive salaries at #non-profit #hospitals: http://t.co/mfAmnK8drb — State of Reform (@StateofReform) January 19, 2015
